Yama and Niyama

Yama and Niyama are typically known as "the Ten Commandments of Yoga." Each certainly one of these Five Don'ts (Yama) and 5 Do's (Niyama) can be a supporting, liberating Pillar of Yoga. Yama signifies self-restraint inside the sensation of self-mastery, or abstention, and consists of five elements. Niyama signifies observances, of which there are actually also five. Here is the full record of these 10 Pillars as given in Yoga Sutras 2:30,32:

1) Ahimsa: non-violence, non-injury, harmlessness

2) Satya: truthfulness, honesty

3) Asteya: non-stealing, honesty, non-misappropriativeness

8) Tapas: austerity, useful (i.e., result-producing) spiritual discipline

All of those cope with the innate powers in the human being-or rather with all the abstinence and observance which will develop and launch these powers to be made use of toward our non secular perfection, to our self-realization and liberation.

These 10 restraints (yama) and observances (niyama) usually are not optional for that aspiring yogi-or for essentially the most advanced yogi, either.
